node.title: Mystery of the killer plant that sucks in and eats animals
node.alt: The purple trap looks like a bladder attached to the stem of a plant. There is an obvious opening where animals are sucked in
node.description: Its hunting strategy sounds messy, but isÂ so stealthy, rapid and brutally efficient that nobody knows precisely which species are being caught in its terrifying trap.
node.content:
["On a wetland east of Esperance, Thilo Krueger is trying to crack a baffling case.", "He is wading through the habitat of the\u00a0world's fastest-moving predatory plant, which survives\u00a0by sucking animals into a trap and eating them alive.", "Although the hunting tactics sound messy, they are in fact so covert that no one has managed to identify exactly what species of animals the plants are ingesting.", "Mr Krueger, a PhD student at Curtin University, hopes to change that.", "", "
Thilo Krueger,\u00a0Zoe Bullen, Duarne Close and Donna Beach.\u00a0(ABC News: Emily Smith)
", "Mr Krueger is interested in a particular type of carnivorous plant called bladderworts, of the genus Utricularia, known as\u00a0\"the fastest moving predatory plant in the world\" because of its system for trapping animals.", "", "
A close-up image of the trap on the predatory bladderworts, which it uses to trap and eat animals.(Supplied: Thilo Krueger)
", "The\u00a0plant has an underwater bladder attached to its stem, which is surrounded by small hairs that act as trip-wires.", "When an animal moves past the trip-wire, it triggers the bladder to open and\u00a0suck\u00a0the prey inside.", "This happens in a fraction of a millisecond;\u00a0more than 100 times more quickly than a Venus fly trap.\u00a0", "The animal is then digested within the bladder structure.", "
What are the plants eating?\u00a0
", "Mr Krueger plans to use a technique called DNA metabarcoding to work out what species of animal the plants are eating.", "Adam Cross, an ecologist from Curtin University, said that previous studies of the bladderwort's diet\u00a0had involved\u00a0looking at the traps under a microscope and trying to see what was there.", "", "
The small sac-like structures are where the plants suck\u00a0in animals to eat.\u00a0(Supplied: Thilo Krueger)
", "But he explained that as the traps are so small, and as much of the prey was partially digested, it was very difficult to determine visually.", "But a DNA comparison should be much more accurate.\u00a0", "", "
The twining\u00a0utricularia helix is endemic to the Esperance area.(Supplied: Thilo Krueger)
", "The\u00a0first stage of this technique\u00a0requires\u00a0Mr Krueger to collect samples of the plant traps, which he did near Esperance last week.\u00a0", "", "
The\u00a0traps, which the plant uses to catch and eat small animals, are easily visible on stems fanning out from the plant.(Supplied: David Guilfoyle)
", "He will then send them to a laboratory\u00a0to\u00a0sequence all the DNA found in the trap.", "That will then be compared to a library of known animal DNA sequences, and hopefully reveal exactly what species are inside each trap.", "This will also allow them to compare the dietary differences between\u00a0bladderwort species.\u00a0", "Mr Krueger\u00a0says\u00a0the diets are\u00a0likely to include small crustaceans, like ostracods, copepods and water fleas.\u00a0", "
Low rainfall, farming runoff may threaten species
", "Donna Beach, an elder and ranger from the Esperance Tjaltjraak Native Title Corporation, is part of a team of local rangers helping Mr Krueger last week.", "", "
Thilo Krueger and Donna Beach look for bladderwort samples.\u00a0(Supplied: David Guilfoyle)
", "She was excited to learn the unique species thrived on her country, Kepa Kurl Boodja, and was keen to help conserve them.", "Mr Krueger believes\u00a0that conservation work will\u00a0be crucial, given the plants needed low-nutrient wetlands to survive, and these will\u00a0likely suffer if rainfall reduced and high-nutrient runoff from farming properties made its way to their habitats.", "", "
The low-nutrient habitat around Esperance is ideal for bladderworts, as they get nutrients by eating animals.\u00a0(Supplied: David Guilfoyle)
", "Esperance is known for soil that is poor in nutrients\u00a0and Mr Krueger says\u00a0that is why bladderworts have adapted to instead get their nutrients from animals.", "While there are about 250 species globally, nine are found near Esperance, and two of them\u00a0are endemic to the region.\u00a0", "\"Most of these species we do have in cultivation, so people in botanic gardens for example do grow them,\" he said.", "\"But I would argue that the most important thing is really to make sure the plants are safe in their natural environment.\""]
